results.title: India's history: British Colony to independence
results.brief_description: The centuries during which India’s people strove for independence, the role of the British East India Company, the realisation of independence, and the creation of Pakistan and the Union of India are examined. The film also presents the influence of Mohandas Gandhi, the changing relations between India and Britain, and the problems confronting India’s two great people - Hindus and Muslims.

results.title: India's history: Mogul empire to european colonization
results.brief_description: Beginning with the rule of the Delhi Sultans in the 13th century, the film traces the subsequent growth of the powerful and enlightened empire of the Moguls, the decline of these rulers, the rise of European interest in India, and the conflict between Britain and France for control of Indian trade, culminating in the Battle of Plassey in 1760.

results.title: India's history: early civilization
results.brief_description: Exploring the basic influences that shaped the beginnings of India’s long and complex history, this survey recounts the early days of original inhabitants, of invasions, and of the rise of great leaders - Buddha, Chandragupta Maurya, and Asoka. The cultural contributions, notably Buddhism and Hinduism, made by successive peoples are seen to have their origins in early India.

results.title: India, Pakistan and the Union of India
results.brief_description: An account of the geography and sociological conditions existing in present-day India: Hindu and Muslim religions; important economic problems as experienced by a typical peasant family; industry in India; climatic conditions - a period of drought followed by the monsoon season; the spread of education and its effect on the industrial and agricultural life of the country.

results.title: Woodwinds and dance
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
One of a series of films recording the various aspects of daily life among the remote tribes of Indians in the South American jungles. Using large pieces of bamboo, two young men make bassoon like instruments, which are used in a village dance.

results.title: Indian village
results.brief_description: Sucksdorff, the distinguished Swedish director visited India in 1951 and made two films “Wind and the river” and “Indian village”. “Indian village” was intended to be shown throughout India to persuade peasants to discard their centuries-old methods of cultivation and village administration and to adopt modern methods of co-operation. The story Sucksdorff has chosen is centred on a village in which the people are dependent on an old well which dries up in the hot season, bringing drought and starvation.

results.title: Indian Ocean
results.brief_description: Describes the growth of the Empire round the Indian Ocean. Barred from the East Indies, the British established themselves on the mainland of India, where they were followed by the French. The rivalry of these two great nations led to their entry into the politics of India, and intense trading, political and naval rivalry until the fall of Napoleon in 1815.

results.title: Indian festival
results.brief_description: A survey of the festivals of India, seasonal and religious, which take place in large and small communities throughout the land and during all months of the year. Vast numbers of people take part in processions, rituals, re-creations of events, songs and dances to request the assistance of various gods or to thank them for their help during the past year. Brief glimpses of some art forms and decorations associated with the ceremonies are shown.

results.title: Indian fantasy
results.brief_description: Intended as one episode in a full length animated and colour feature cartoon of Jules Verne’s “Round the World in Eighty Days”, this sequence shows the beginning and end of the journey and the adventures of Phileas Fogg and his servant in India. The film was commenced in 1938 but was not completed.
